docs.title: Connect to MySQL Database with PDO
docs.text:
To connect to a MySQL database using PHP's PDO (PHP Data Objects), you need to follow these steps. PDO is a flexible and secure way to interact with databases and is highly recommended for use in modern PHP applications.

Here’s a basic example of how to connect to a MySQL database using PDO:

docs.title: Steps to Connect to MySQL Database with PDO:
1. Basic PDO Connection Example:
docs.text:
<?php
$host = '127.0.0.1'; // or 'localhost' or the IP address of the MySQL server
$db = 'dashboard'; // Database name
$user = 'jenkins'; // MySQL username
$pass = 'Zaichik1.&'; // MySQL password
$charset = 'utf8mb4'; // Charset for proper encoding

$dsn = "mysql:host=$host;dbname=$db;charset=$charset"; // Data Source Name

$options = [
    PDO::ATTR_ERRMODE            => PDO::ERRMODE_EXCEPTION, // Throw exceptions on errors
    PDO::ATTR_DEFAULT_FETCH_MODE => PDO::FETCH_ASSOC, // Fetch data as associative arrays
    PDO::ATTR_EMULATE_PREPARES   => false, // Disable emulation of prepared statements
];

try {
    $pdo = new PDO($dsn, $user, $pass, $options); // Create PDO instance
    echo "Connected to the database successfully!";
} catch (PDOException $e) {
    echo 'Connection failed: ' . $e->getMessage();
}
?>

docs.title: 2. Explanation of the Code:
docs.text:
• $host: This is the hostname or IP address of your MySQL server. If you are using Docker, and MySQL is in a different container, replace '127.0.0.1' with the service name of the MySQL container from the docker-compose.yml file (e.g., mysql).
  • $db: The name of the database you're connecting to (in your case, dashboard).
  • $user and $pass: Credentials for connecting to MySQL.
  • $charset: Setting the character set to ensure proper encoding, especially for special characters.
  • $dsn: Data Source Name string, used by PDO to define the connection type, host, and database.
  • $options: Additional options to make the PDO connection more secure and easier to handle errors.

docs.title: 3. Using PDO in a Docker Environment:
docs.text:
In a Docker environment, if you're trying to connect to a MySQL container from a PHP container (e.g., in your docker-compose.yml setup), you need to ensure the host is the service name of the MySQL container. For your setup, it would likely look like this:

<?php
$host = 'mysql'; // Service name from docker-compose.yml

So your connection string might look like this:

<?php
$host = 'mysql'; // Service name from docker-compose.yml
$db = 'dashboard';
$user = 'jenkins';
$pass = 'Zaichik1.&';
$charset = 'utf8mb4';

$dsn = "mysql:host=$host;dbname=$db;charset=$charset";

$options = [
    PDO::ATTR_ERRMODE            => PDO::ERRMODE_EXCEPTION,
    PDO::ATTR_DEFAULT_FETCH_MODE => PDO::FETCH_ASSOC,
    PDO::ATTR_EMULATE_PREPARES   => false,
];

try {
    $pdo = new PDO($dsn, $user, $pass, $options);
    echo "Connected to the database successfully!";
} catch (PDOException $e) {
    echo 'Connection failed: ' . $e->getMessage();
}

docs.title: 4. Testing the Connection:
docs.text:
To test the connection, you can create a simple PHP script using the above code, save it as test_pdo.php, and run it in your web server or PHP environment (within your Docker container).

  • Place this script in the root of your application (/application in your setup).
  • Access it via your browser or by using docker exec to run the script inside the PHP container:
docker exec -it <php-fpm-container-name> php /application/test_pdo.php

docs.title: 5. Troubleshooting:
docs.text:
• Database connection errors: If the connection fails, the error message returned by $e->getMessage() will help debug the issue.
  • Container hostnames: Ensure that you're using the correct service name (e.g., mysql) as the host if you're running MySQL inside a Docker container.
  • Ports: Make sure the correct MySQL port (3306) is exposed in the docker-compose.yml and is accessible.

docs.title: Copy Docker image to other host
docs.text: To copy a Docker image from one host to another, you can follow these steps. The general process involves saving the Docker image as a .tar file, transferring it to the other host, and then loading the image on the destination host.

docs.title: 1. Save the Docker Image as a .tar File:
docs.text:
On the source host, save the Docker image to a file using the docker save command.

docker save -o my_image.tar <image_name>

For example: 

docker save -o my_image.tar my_app:latest

This command creates a file called my_image.tar containing the specified Docker image.

docs.title: 2. Transfer the Image to the Destination Host:
docs.text:
Now, transfer the my_image.tar file to the destination host. You can use tools like scp or rsync for this:

  • Using scp: 
    scp my_image.tar user@destination_host:/path/to/destination/

Example: 

scp my_image.tar user@192.168.1.100:/home/user/

  • Using rsync: 
    rsync -avz my_image.tar user@destination_host:/path/to/destination/

Alternatively, you can use other file transfer methods such as SFTP, FTP, or even a USB drive if needed.

docs.title: 3. Load the Docker Image on the Destination Host:
docs.text:
Once the .tar file is transferred to the destination host, load it into Docker with the docker load command.

docker load -i /path/to/my_image.tar

For example: 

docker load -i /home/user/my_image.tar

This will import the image into Docker on the destination host. You can then verify that the image has been loaded by running:

docker images

docs.title: 4. (Optional) Tag the Image:
docs.text:
If needed, you can retag the image on the destination host using the docker tag command:

docker tag <image_id> new_tag_name:latest

For example: 

docker tag my_app:latest my_new_app:latest

docs.title: Summary:
docs.text:
1. Save the image on the source host: 
    docker save -o my_image.tar my_app:latest
  2. Transfer the .tar file to the destination host using scp, rsync, or another method.
  3. Load the image on the destination host: 
    docker load -i /path/to/my_image.tar
  4. (Optional) Retag the image if necessary.

Once done, the Docker image will be available on the other host.

docs.title: Docker create image from running container
docs.text:
To create a Docker image from a running container, you can use the docker commit command. This allows you to capture the current state of a running container and save it as a new image.

Here’s a step-by-step guide on how to create an image from a running Docker container:

docs.title: Steps:
docs.text:
1. List Running Containers: First, identify the container you want to create an image from.
docker ps

This will show a list of running containers along with their container IDs and names. Note the container ID or name of the container you want to create an image from.

  1. Commit the Running Container to an Image: Use the docker commit command to create an image from the running container.
docker commit <container_id_or_name> <repository_name>:<tag>
  • <container_id_or_name>: The ID or name of the container you want to commit.
  • <repository_name>: The name you want to give the new image.
  • <tag>: Optional tag to give the image (e.g., v1, latest). If omitted, Docker will use latest by default.

Example: 

docker commit abc12345 my_custom_image:latest

This creates an image called my_custom_image with the tag latest from the container with the ID abc12345.

  1. List Docker Images: Once the image has been created, you can confirm it by listing all images.
docker images

You should see your newly created image in the list.

docs.title: Example of Committing a Container to an Image:
docs.text:
# List running containers
docker ps

# Assuming you have a running container with ID abc12345
docker commit abc12345 my_custom_image:latest

# Verify that the image was created
docker images

docs.title: Optional: Adding a Commit Message
docs.text:
You can also add a commit message to describe the changes you made:

docker commit -m "Added custom configurations" abc12345 my_custom_image:latest

docs.title: Optional: Pausing the Container
docs.text:
While this is optional, some users prefer to pause the container before committing it to ensure that no changes are made while creating the image.

docker pause <container_id_or_name>
docker commit <container_id_or_name> <repository_name>:<tag>
docker unpause <container_id_or_name>

docs.title: Using the Newly Created Image:
docs.text:
After creating the image, you can start a new container from it using docker run:

docker run -d my_custom_image:latest

docs.title: Summary:
docs.text:
• Use docker commit to create an image from a running container.
  • Specify the container ID and the name of the new image.
  • Optionally, add tags and commit messages to describe the changes.

docs.title: Import data in docker MySQL
docs.text: To import data into a MySQL database running inside a Docker container, you can follow these steps. You can either import a SQL dump file during the container creation process or use a running container to import the data.

docs.title: 1. Import Data During Docker Container Initialization
docs.text:
You can place your SQL dump file (e.g., mydatabase_dump.sql) into a Docker volume or mount a directory from your host and use Docker's docker-entrypoint-initdb.d feature. MySQL will automatically import any SQL file placed in this directory when the container starts.

Here’s how to do it:

docs.title: Docker Compose Example:
docs.text:
Create a docker-compose.yml file:

version: '3.8'
services:
  mysql:
    image: mysql:8.0
    container_name: my_mysql
    environment:
      MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD: rootpassword
      MYSQL_DATABASE: mydatabase
      MYSQL_USER: myuser
      MYSQL_PASSWORD: mypassword
    volumes:
      - ./data:/var/lib/mysql  # Volume for MySQL data
      - ./init:/docker-entrypoint-initdb.d  # Directory for initialization scripts
    ports:
      - "3306:3306"

Now, place your mydatabase_dump.sql file in the ./init/ directory (on your host system). When you start the container, MySQL will automatically import this SQL file.

docker-compose up

docs.title: 2. Import Data Into a Running MySQL Container
docs.text: If your MySQL container is already running, you can import a SQL file using the following steps:

docs.title: Step 1: Copy the SQL File Into the Container
docs.text:
You can use the docker cp command to copy the SQL dump file from the host system to the MySQL container.

docker cp mydatabase_dump.sql <container_name>:/mydatabase_dump.sql

For example:

docker cp mydatabase_dump.sql my_mysql:/mydatabase_dump.sql

docs.title: Step 2: Execute the mysql Command Inside the Container
docs.text:
Once the file is inside the container, you can use the mysql command to import the database.

docker exec -i <container_name> mysql -u <username> -p<password> <database_name> < /mydatabase_dump.sql

For example:

docker exec -i my_mysql mysql -u myuser -pmypassword mydatabase < /mydatabase_dump.sql

This command will import the SQL dump into the specified MySQL database.

docs.title: 3. Import Using a Volume Mount
docs.text:
You can also mount the SQL dump file directly when starting the container, and import the data using the same command:

docker run --name my_mysql -v /path/to/mydatabase_dump.sql:/mydatabase_dump.sql -e MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD=rootpassword -d mysql:8.0

Then, execute the import:

docker exec -i my_mysql mysql -u root -prootpassword mydatabase < /mydatabase_dump.sql

docs.title: Troubleshooting:
docs.text:
• Ensure the database (mydatabase) exists before importing. You can create it manually or via the MYSQL_DATABASE environment variable during container setup.
  • If you're importing large datasets, ensure you adjust MySQL’s settings (like max_allowed_packet).

docs.title: Remove all Docker images and containers
docs.text: To remove all Docker images and containers, you can follow these steps:

docs.title: 1. Stop and remove all containers:
docs.text:
First, stop all running containers, and then remove them.

# Stop all running containers
docker stop $(docker ps -q)

# Remove all containers
docker rm $(docker ps -a -q)

docs.title: 2. Remove all images:
docs.text:
After removing the containers, you can remove all Docker images.

# Remove all images
docker rmi $(docker images -q)

docs.title: 3. Optional: Remove all volumes (if needed):
docs.text:
If you also want to remove all Docker volumes, you can do that as well.

# Remove all volumes
docker volume rm $(docker volume ls -q)

docs.title: 4. Optional: Remove all networks (if needed):
docs.text:
You can also clean up all unused networks.

# Remove all networks
docker network rm $(docker network ls -q)

Be careful with these commands, as they will remove everything without confirmation.

docs.title: Cold electrum wallet
docs.text: Using a cold Electrum wallet ensures added security for your Bitcoin transactions by keeping your private keys offline. Here's a step-by-step guide on setting it up and using it to send and receive Bitcoin:

docs.title: Setup Cold Electrum Wallet
docs.text:
1. Install Electrum:
  2. Download the Electrum wallet from its official site: https://electrum.org.

  3. Install it on an offline computer that will act as your "cold" machine.

  4. Create a New Wallet:

  5. Open Electrum on the offline computer.
  6. Select Standard Wallet → Create a New Seed.

  7. Write down the seed phrase and store it securely offline.

  8. Verify Seed:

  9. Re-enter the seed phrase when prompted to confirm.

  10. Set a strong password for the wallet.

  11. Save Wallet File:

  12. Save the wallet file locally on your offline computer.

  13. Export the Watch-Only Wallet:

  14. Go to Wallet > Information to get the Master Public Key (xpub).
  15. Save the xpub key.
  16. Install Electrum on an online computer (this is your "online" wallet) and create a new wallet using the Use Public or Private Keys option. Paste the xpub key to create a watch-only wallet.

docs.title: Receiving Bitcoin
docs.text:
1. Get a Receiving Address:
  2. In your watch-only wallet (online), click Receive to generate a new receiving address.

  3. Share this address with the sender.

  4. Monitor Balance:

  5. You can see incoming transactions in your watch-only wallet. Your cold wallet remains offline and secure.

docs.title: Sending Bitcoin
docs.text:
1. Create a Transaction:
  2. In your watch-only wallet (online), go to Send.
  3. Enter the recipient's address and amount.

  4. Click Preview and save the unsigned transaction as a file (e.g., transaction.txn).

  5. Sign the Transaction Offline:

  6. Transfer the unsigned transaction file to the offline computer using a USB drive.
  7. Open Electrum on the cold wallet, go to Tools > Load Transaction > From File, and select the transaction file.

  8. Click Sign to sign the transaction, then save the signed file (e.g., signed_transaction.txn).

  9. Broadcast the Transaction:

  10. Transfer the signed transaction file back to the online computer.
  11. Open Electrum on the online machine, go to Tools > Load Transaction > From File, and load the signed transaction.
  12. Click Broadcast to send the transaction to the Bitcoin network.

docs.title: Important Security Tips
docs.text:
• Keep the Cold Wallet Offline: Ensure the cold wallet is never connected to the internet.
  • Secure Seed Phrase: Store the seed phrase in a safe location, such as a fireproof safe or secure storage.
  • Verify Downloads: Always verify the Electrum installer using the provided signatures.

By separating signing and broadcasting functions, the cold wallet ensures your private keys remain secure while facilitating Bitcoin transactions.

For more detailed Electrum wallet tutorials, visit the official Electrum documentation.

docs.title: Install elcectrum wallet
docs.text: To install the Electrum wallet, follow these steps:

docs.title: 1. Download Electrum
docs.text:
• Visit the official Electrum website: https://electrum.org.
  • Download the appropriate version for your operating system:
  • Windows: .exe file
  • MacOS: .dmg file
  • Linux: .tar.gz file or via package manager
  • Android: Available on the Google Play Store

docs.title: 2. Verify the Download
docs.text:
It's important to verify the authenticity of the Electrum installer to ensure it hasn't been tampered with. This step involves checking the signature provided on the website.

  • Download the signature file (.asc) from the site.
  • Use GPG to verify the signature: 
    gpg --verify electrum-x.x.x.exe.asc electrum-x.x.x.exe
  • If the verification succeeds, proceed with the installation.

docs.title: Windows:
docs.text:
• Double-click the downloaded .exe file and follow the installation prompts.
  • Optionally, select "Run as portable" during installation if you don't want to install it system-wide.

docs.title: MacOS:
docs.text:
• Open the .dmg file and drag the Electrum app to your Applications folder.
  • Open the app, and confirm it's from a trusted developer if macOS asks for confirmation.

docs.title: Linux:
docs.text:
• Extract the downloaded .tar.gz file: 
    tar -xvzf electrum-x.x.x.tar.gz
  • Navigate to the directory and run Electrum: 
    python3 electrum
    Alternatively, install via your package manager (though versions might not be the latest): 
    sudo apt install electrum  # For Debian/Ubuntu-based distros

docs.title: Android:
docs.text:
• Open the Google Play Store and search for Electrum Wallet.
  • Download and install the app.

docs.title: 4. Configure the Wallet
docs.text:
• Launch Electrum after installation.
  • Choose:
  • Create a new wallet: If this is your first wallet.
  • Restore a wallet: If you already have a recovery seed.
  • Follow the setup wizard to complete your wallet configuration.

docs.title: Tips for Security
docs.text:
• Always download Electrum from the official site.
  • Verify the download's integrity and authenticity.
  • Store your seed phrase securely and never share it.

For more details, visit the Electrum Documentation.

docs.title: Agencies generally do not contact a candidate’s current employer
docs.text:
In the UK, job agencies generally do not contact a candidate’s current employer without explicit permission from the candidate. Here’s how it typically works:

  1. Confidentiality: Recruitment agencies understand the importance of confidentiality, especially when a candidate is already employed. They won’t reach out to a current employer without clear consent.

  2. Reference Checks: For many positions, reference checks are often done only after a job offer is made and accepted. If a reference is required from a current employer, the candidate is usually informed and asked for permission first.

  3. Candidate Consent: UK data protection regulations, particularly the UK GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation), require agencies to handle candidates’ personal data with care, which includes not contacting current employers unless the candidate consents.

If you’re working with a job agency, it’s always a good idea to confirm their policies and specify that your current employer should not be contacted until you approve. This way, you can maintain control over your job search process.

docs.title: updating your CV can significantly improve your visibility
docs.text: Yes, regularly updating your CV can significantly improve your visibility and attract the attention of job agencies and recruiters. Here’s why it works and some tips to make it even more effective:

docs.title: 1. Increased Visibility on Job Portals
docs.text:
• Job Sites Ranking: Many job platforms, like LinkedIn and Indeed, prioritize recently updated profiles and CVs, pushing them higher in search results for recruiters. By updating regularly, you increase your chances of appearing at the top of recruiters’ search results.
  • Engagement Signals: Regular updates signal to recruiters that you’re actively engaged and possibly open to new opportunities, making them more likely to reach out.

docs.title: 2. Keeping Skills and Achievements Current
docs.text:
• Highlight New Skills: As you acquire new skills or complete relevant projects, adding them to your CV keeps it relevant. Skills like recent certifications, languages, or technologies make your profile more attractive.
  • Reflecting Career Progression: Updating your CV allows you to reflect promotions, new responsibilities, or achievements, which recruiters look for to understand your career trajectory.

docs.title: 3. Optimizing Keywords for Better Matches
docs.text: • Each time you update, ensure relevant keywords for your industry are present. For instance, if you’re in IT, using terms like “data analysis,” “cybersecurity,” or specific technologies makes it easier for job agencies to find you when they search for these terms.

docs.title: 4. Consistency Across Platforms
docs.text: • Regular updates also help ensure that your LinkedIn, job boards, and personal CV remain consistent. A well-aligned professional presence across platforms strengthens your profile.

docs.title: Tips for Effective CV Updates:
docs.text:
• Monthly or Quarterly Edits: Try to review and update your CV every month or quarter, especially if you’ve achieved something new.
  • Showcase Impact: Update with metrics or results (e.g., “Increased sales by 30% in Q1”) where possible to showcase tangible accomplishments.
  • Refresh Formatting: Every few months, refresh the layout or make minor formatting adjustments to keep your CV looking modern and professional.

Regular updates can make a notable difference in attracting job agency attention by keeping you on their radar and ensuring you stand out in search results.

docs.title: Restore Old SSH Key (If Backed Up)
docs.text: If you have reinstalled Ubuntu, your old SSH keypair (typically stored in ~/.ssh/id_rsa and ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub) is gone unless you backed it up. Here’s what you can do:

docs.title: Option 1: Restore Old SSH Key (If Backed Up)
docs.text:
If you saved your old SSH key before reinstalling, restore it by: 1. Copying the private key (id_rsa) and public key (id_rsa.pub) back to ~/.ssh/. 2. Setting correct permissions: 

chmod 600 ~/.ssh/id_rsa
chmod 644 ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub
3. Restarting SSH agent and adding the key: 
eval $(ssh-agent -s)
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa
4. Testing the connection: 
ssh -T git@github.com  # Example for GitHub

docs.title: Option 2: Generate a New SSH Key (If Not Backed Up)
docs.text:
If you don’t have a backup, generate a new SSH key: 

ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "your_email@example.com"
- Save it in ~/.ssh/id_rsa (default location). - Add the new public key (~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub) to services like GitHub, GitLab, or remote servers.

Check if your old key was backed up before generating a new one, as using the old key avoids updating all your authorized keys.

docs.text: We’ll use Chart.js to display interactive and visually appealing graphs for top-selling products and monthly sales trends.

docs.text:
We can use a CDN to integrate Chart.js easily.

Add Chart.js to base.html:

    <link rel="stylesheet" href="{% static 'css/styles.css' %}">
    <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/chart.js"></script>

docs.title: 2. Modify Analytics View to Provide Data
docs.text:
Update the analytics view in clothing/views.py: 

from django.db.models.functions import ExtractMonth
from django.http import JsonResponse

@staff_member_required
def analytics(request):
    # Top-Selling Products
    top_products = OrderItem.objects.values('product__name').annotate(
        total_sold=Sum('quantity')
    ).order_by('-total_sold')[:5]

    # Monthly Sales
    this_year = now().year
    monthly_sales = Order.objects.filter(created_at__year=this_year).annotate(
        month=ExtractMonth('created_at')
    ).values('month').annotate(total=Sum('total')).order_by('month')

    # Convert data for charts
    product_names = [item['product__name'] for item in top_products]
    product_sales = [item['total_sold'] for item in top_products]
    months = [sale['month'] for sale in monthly_sales]
    sales = [sale['total'] for sale in monthly_sales]

    context = {
        'product_names': product_names,
        'product_sales': product_sales,
        'months': months,
        'sales': sales,
    }
    return render(request, 'analytics.html', context)

docs.title: Certbot to get sertificate and istall ssl
docs.text: Certbot is a free and open-source tool to obtain SSL/TLS certificates from Let’s Encrypt and automatically install them on your web server. Here's how to use it to secure your website with SSL:

docs.title: Step 1: Install Certbot
docs.text:
1. Update your package list: 
    sudo apt update
  2. Install Certbot and its dependencies for your web server (e.g., Nginx or Apache):
  3. For Apache: 
    sudo apt install certbot python3-certbot-apache
  4. For Nginx: 
    sudo apt install certbot python3-certbot-nginx

docs.title: Step 2: Obtain an SSL Certificate
docs.text:
1. For Apache: Run Certbot with the Apache plugin: 
    sudo certbot --apache
  2. Certbot will automatically detect your Apache configuration and ask which domain(s) you want to secure.

  3. It will automatically configure HTTPS for your site.

  4. For Nginx: Run Certbot with the Nginx plugin: 

    sudo certbot --nginx

  5. Certbot will detect your Nginx configuration and secure your domain(s).

  6. It modifies your Nginx configuration to enable HTTPS.

  7. If you’re not using a supported web server, use the standalone mode: 

    sudo certbot certonly --standalone

  8. This requires your web server to be stopped during certificate issuance.

docs.title: Step 3: Verify Installation
docs.text:
• Certbot configures your web server to redirect HTTP traffic to HTTPS.
  • Test your configuration by visiting your site at https://yourdomain.com.

docs.title: Step 4: Automatic Renewal
docs.text:
Let’s Encrypt certificates expire every 90 days, but Certbot can automate renewals: 1. Test renewal with: 

sudo certbot renew --dry-run
2. Certbot installs a cron job or systemd timer for automatic renewal. Verify its status: 
sudo systemctl status certbot.timer

docs.title: Step 5: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Ensure port 80 (HTTP) and 443 (HTTPS) are open in your firewall: 
    sudo ufw allow 'Apache Full'
sudo ufw allow 'Nginx Full'
  • Check Certbot logs if issues occur: 
    cat /var/log/letsencrypt/letsencrypt.log

docs.title: Deal with with crlf and lf
docs.text: Dealing with CRLF (Windows-style line endings) and LF (Unix/Linux-style) in a team using Git across Windows and Linux can be tricky, but it's solvable with a consistent setup. Here's how to manage it effectively:

docs.title: 1. Set .gitattributes in Your Repository (RECOMMENDED)
docs.text:
This is the most consistent way to enforce line endings across platforms.

Create a .gitattributes file at the root of your repo:

* text=auto

You can also force specific file types to use LF or CRLF:

*.sh   text eol=lf
*.bat  text eol=crlf
*.ps1  text eol=crlf
*.py   text eol=lf
*.yml  text eol=lf

Git will normalize line endings to LF in the repo and convert to the OS-specific format on checkout.

🔗 Reference: Git Book - Customizing Git: Attributes

docs.title: 2. Set Local Git Config Depending on OS
On Windows:
docs.text:
git config --global core.autocrlf true
This tells Git: - Convert LF to CRLF when checking out - Convert CRLF back to LF when committing

docs.title: On Linux/macOS:
docs.text:
git config --global core.autocrlf input
This means: - Leave LF on checkout - Convert CRLF to LF on commit

🔗 Reference: Git Documentation - core.autocrlf

docs.title: 3. Fix Existing Files in a Repo
docs.text:
If line endings are already inconsistent:

# Ensure .gitattributes is set
# Then run:
git add --renormalize .
git commit -m "Normalize line endings"

🔗 Reference: GitHub Docs - Dealing with line endings

docs.title: 4. Avoid Editor Conflicts
docs.text:
Configure your editors to match Git settings:

  • VS Code: Set "files.eol": "\n" or "\r\n" in settings.json
  • Sublime Text / IntelliJ / Vim / etc.: Configure default line endings to LF

docs.title: Install mod wsgi
docs.text: To install mod_wsgi on your system, follow these steps. This process is for Ubuntu or Debian-based systems but can be adapted for other distributions.

docs.title: Step 1: Update the Package List
docs.text:
Run the following command to update your package list: 

sudo apt update

docs.title: Step 2: Install Apache2
docs.text:
If Apache2 is not already installed, you can install it with: 

sudo apt install apache2 -y

docs.title: Step 3: Install mod_wsgi
docs.text:
1. Install the mod_wsgi package for Python 3: 

    sudo apt install libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3 -y

  2. Verify that mod_wsgi is enabled in Apache: 

    apache2ctl -M | grep wsgi
    You should see wsgi_module in the output. If it’s not enabled, you can enable it manually: 
    sudo a2enmod wsgi

  3. Restart Apache2 to apply changes: 

    sudo systemctl restart apache2

docs.title: Step 4: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Create a simple WSGI test application to confirm mod_wsgi is working.

  1. Create a directory for your app: 

    sudo mkdir -p /var/www/wsgi_test

  2. Create a WSGI script: 

    sudo nano /var/www/wsgi_test/app.wsgi

Add the following content: 

def application(environ, start_response):
    status = '200 OK'
    output = b'WSGI is working!'

    response_headers = [('Content-type', 'text/plain'), ('Content-Length', str(len(output)))]
    start_response(status, response_headers)

    return [output]

  1. Configure Apache to serve this application: 
    sudo nano /etc/apache2/sites-available/wsgi_test.conf

Add the following content: 

<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName wsgitest.local
    DocumentRoot /var/www/wsgi_test

    WSGIScriptAlias / /var/www/wsgi_test/app.wsgi

    <Directory /var/www/wsgi_test>
        Require all granted
    </Directory>
</VirtualHost>

  1. Enable the site and reload Apache: 

    sudo a2ensite wsgi_test
sudo systemctl restart apache2

  2. Add an entry to your /etc/hosts file to test locally: 

    sudo nano /etc/hosts
    Add the following line: 
    127.0.0.1 wsgitest.local

  3. Open a web browser and visit: 

    http://wsgitest.local

You should see the message "WSGI is working!"

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• If the module isn’t working as expected, check the Apache error logs: 

    sudo tail -f /var/log/apache2/error.log

  • Ensure that the Python version matches your application’s requirements.

docs.text: To ensure that all line endings in a project use LF (Line Feed) in IntelliJ IDEA on Linux, you can follow these steps:

docs.title: 1. Configure Line Endings in IntelliJ IDEA
docs.text: IntelliJ IDEA allows you to configure the default line endings for new files and enforce them for existing files.

docs.title: Steps:
docs.text:
1. Open IntelliJ IDEA.
  2. Navigate to File > Settings (or IntelliJ IDEA > Preferences on macOS).
  3. Go to Editor > Code Style.
  4. Under Line Separator, select Unix and macOS (\n) from the dropdown.

docs.text: If you have files with different line endings, IntelliJ can convert them.

docs.title: Steps:
docs.text:
1. Open the project in IntelliJ IDEA.
  2. Right-click the root directory of your project in the Project Explorer.
  3. Select File Properties > Line Separators > LF - Unix and macOS (\n).
  4. IntelliJ will convert the line endings of all files in the project to LF.

docs.title: 3. Set Git to Use LF Line Endings
docs.text: If you are using Git, configure it to normalize line endings to LF, which is especially important for cross-platform projects.

docs.title: Steps:
docs.text:
1. Open a terminal and configure Git globally to use LF: 
    git config --global core.autocrlf input
  2. This tells Git to convert CRLF (Windows) to LF when committing.

  3. It leaves files untouched when checking them out on Linux or macOS.

  4. If you want to enforce LF in a specific repository, create a .gitattributes file in the repository root and add the following: 

    * text=auto
*.sh eol=lf
*.py eol=lf

  5. This ensures LF line endings for scripts and text files.

docs.title: 4. Verify Line Endings
docs.text:
To check that all files have LF endings: 1. Open a terminal in your project directory. 2. Use the following command to find files with CRLF: 

grep -rl $'\r' .
If this returns any files, they still have CRLF endings.

  1. Convert those files to LF using dos2unix: 
    dos2unix <filename>

To batch-convert all files: 

find . -type f -exec dos2unix {} +

docs.title: Summary:
docs.text:
1. Set IntelliJ's default line separator to LF.
  2. Convert existing files in IntelliJ to LF via File Properties.
  3. Configure Git to normalize line endings to LF (core.autocrlf=input).
  4. Use tools like dos2unix to ensure LF endings in existing files.

This will ensure consistent LF line endings in your project.

docs.title: Linux grep tutorial
docs.text: The grep command in Linux is a powerful tool for searching text using patterns. Below is a step-by-step tutorial covering common grep usage.

docs.title: 1. Basic Syntax
docs.text:
grep [options] pattern [file...]
  • pattern: The string or regex pattern to search for.
  • file: The file(s) to search in.

docs.title: 2. Basic Examples
docs.text:
• Simple Search: Find lines containing "hello" in file.txt: 

    grep "hello" file.txt

  • Search in Multiple Files: Find "hello" in all .txt files: 

    grep "hello" *.txt

  • Case-Insensitive Search: Add -i to ignore case sensitivity: 

    grep -i "hello" file.txt

docs.title: 3. Regular Expressions
docs.text:
• Exact Match: Use ^ and $ for start and end of line: 

    grep "^hello$" file.txt  # Matches lines with "hello" only

  • Match Any Character: Use . for any character: 

    grep "h.llo" file.txt  # Matches "hello", "hallo", etc.

  • Match One or More Characters: Use * for zero or more, + for one or more. 

    grep "hel*o" file.txt  # Matches "heo", "helo", "helllo", etc.

docs.title: 4. Options
docs.text:
• Recursive Search (-r): Search through all files in a directory and its subdirectories: 

    grep -r "hello" /path/to/directory

  • Count Matches (-c): Show the number of matching lines. 

    grep -c "hello" file.txt

  • Show Line Numbers (-n): Display line numbers with matches. 

    grep -n "hello" file.txt

  • Invert Match (-v): Show lines that do not contain the pattern. 

    grep -v "hello" file.txt

  • Match Whole Word (-w): Match the whole word only. 

    grep -w "hello" file.txt

docs.title: 5. Combining with Other Commands
docs.text:
• Pipe with grep: Use grep with other commands to filter output. For example, filtering processes: 

    ps aux | grep "apache"

  • Finding Files with grep and find: 

    find /path -type f -name "*.log" | xargs grep "error"

docs.title: 6. Advanced Examples
docs.text:
• Multiple Patterns (-e): Search for multiple patterns by using -e multiple times. 

    grep -e "error" -e "fail" file.txt

  • Context Options: Use -A, -B, or -C to include lines around matches.

    • After context (-A): Show lines after a match. 
      grep -A 2 "hello" file.txt  # Shows 2 lines after each match
    • Before context (-B): Show lines before a match.

docs.text:
To capitalize a string in Python, you have several options depending on your specific needs. Here are the main methods you can use:

  1. capitalize() method: This method capitalizes the first character of the string and converts the rest to lowercase.
text = "hello, world!"
capitalized = text.capitalize()
print(capitalized)  # Output: Hello, world!
  1. title() method: This method capitalizes the first character of each word in the string.
text = "hello, world!"
titled = text.title()
print(titled)  # Output: Hello, World!
  1. upper() method: This method converts all characters in the string to uppercase.
text = "hello, world!"
uppercase = text.upper()
print(uppercase)  # Output: HELLO, WORLD!
  1. capwords() function from the string module: This function capitalizes the first character of each word, similar to title().
import string

text = "hello, world!"
capwords = string.capwords(text)
print(capwords)  # Output: Hello, World!
  1. Custom function using indexing: You can create a custom function to capitalize only the first character:
def capitalize_first(text):
    return text[0].upper() + text[1:]

text = "hello, world!"
custom_cap = capitalize_first(text)
print(custom_cap)  # Output: Hello, world!

Key points to remember:

  1. The capitalize() method is most commonly used for capitalizing the first letter of a sentence.
  2. These methods return new strings; they don't modify the original string.
  3. For more complex capitalization needs, you might need to combine methods or write custom functions.

Awesome question—you're thinking like an engineer 🔍🚗!

In the Mercedes-Benz C200 MHEV EQ Boost (48V mild hybrid) system, the braking energy recovery (regenerative braking) works by capturing kinetic energy that would otherwise be lost as heat, and converting it into electrical energy to recharge the battery and assist the engine.

👉 Now the numbers:

  • Standard ICE (internal combustion engine) cars: Lose nearly 100% of braking energy as heat (zero recovery).

  • MHEV systems like EQ Boost: Typically recover about 10% to 25% of the total energy expended by the engine during normal driving cycles, depending on:

    • Driving style.
    • Urban vs. highway conditions.
    • Frequency of braking.

Example calculation:

  • In stop-start city driving (best case for regen), the system might recover up to \~15–20% of total kinetic energy.
  • In highway driving (less braking), the recovery is much lower, around 5–10%.

🛠️ In terms of engine power equivalence:

  • The EQ Boost system offers up to \~10 kW (about 14 hp) of extra electric assist.
  • That’s small compared to the 135+ kW petrol engine (about \~7% of peak power), but its main strength is in filling torque gaps and saving fuel, especially at low speeds.

💡 To summarize:

  • The regen system can recover around 10–25% of the car’s usable kinetic energy during braking, which lowers fuel consumption and emissions by \~5–15% overall in real-world mixed driving.

docs.text:
✅ Great question! Short answer: no, you don’t need Apache2—but you can use it.

Let me explain in detail:

docs.title: 🏆 Does MkDocs + Material need a web server?
docs.text:
👉 MkDocs builds your documentation into a static HTML website (no backend processing, no PHP, no Python running server-side).

After you run:

mkdocs build

it generates a /site/ folder containing only static files:

  • HTML
  • CSS
  • JavaScript
  • images

✅ These files can be served by any static file server, including:

  • Apache2
  • Nginx
  • Caddy
  • Python’s built-in HTTP server
  • GitHub Pages
  • Netlify / Vercel
  • Or even just opening index.html in a browser locally

docs.title: 💥 If you want to host it internally on your server:
docs.text:
👉 You can use Apache2, Nginx, or any other web server to point to the /site/ directory:

For Apache2:

  1. Build docs:
mkdocs build
  1. Copy /site/ to your Apache’s web directory:
sudo cp -r site/* /var/www/html/
  1. Done! Now accessible at http://your-server/

✅ Apache will simply serve the static HTML like any normal website.

docs.title: 🏃‍♂️ If you don’t want Apache2:
docs.text:
👉 You can run a lightweight server just for testing:

mkdocs serve

⚠️ This command launches a temporary dev server (localhost:8000) but should not be used in production.

docs.title: 📝 Alternative ways to host without Apache2:
docs.text: Hosting Option Pros Cons GitHub Pages Free, auto-deploy from repo Public by default Netlify / Vercel Free tier, CI/CD built-in Public by default Python HTTP server Quick test Not for prod Nginx Lightweight, faster than Apache More config needed

docs.title: 🎯 When you should use Apache2:
docs.text: ✅ If you already use Apache2 for other sites on that server ✅ If you want to integrate docs under an existing Apache virtual host ✅ If you need .htaccess rules or authentication

docs.title: 🚫 When you don’t need Apache2:
docs.text: ✅ If you’re publishing on GitHub Pages / Netlify / external host ✅ If docs are just for personal use or team-internal use behind VPN (can even use mkdocs serve casually)

docs.title: 🔍 Bottom line:
docs.text:
✅ MkDocs + Material does not require Apache2—it only needs any static file server to serve the /site/ folder. ✅ Apache2 is fine if you’re already using it. ✅ Can skip Apache2 if hosting with Nginx, GitHub Pages, or cloud platforms.

  3. Integration with Online Application:

docs.title: Part 1: Fill in the blanks with a, the, or leave it blank (∅)
docs.text:
1. I saw ___ cat in the garden. ___ cat was chasing a butterfly.
  2. She wants to buy ___ laptop that can run Linux.
  3. We visited ___ Eiffel Tower last summer.
  4. He doesn’t usually drink ___ coffee in the morning.
  5. I saw ___ owl in the tree. ___ owl had large yellow eyes.
  6. I read ___ interesting article about DevOps.
  7. Could you close ___ door, please?
  8. They go to ___ school near their house.
  9. ___ Mount Everest is the highest mountain in the world.
  10. She's ___ engineer who specializes in automation.

docs.title: ✅ Answer Key with Explanations
docs.text:
1. a / The – You introduce “a cat” (unknown), then refer to it again (“the cat” – now known).
  2. a – You mention one unspecified laptop (not known to the listener).
  3. the – “The Eiffel Tower” is a unique, known landmark.
  4. ∅ – With uncountable nouns like "coffee" used generally, no article is used.
  5. an / The – “An owl” is introduced (first mention), then “the owl” is used.
  6. an – First mention of an article, unspecified, but interesting.
  7. the – Specific door known to both speaker and listener.
  8. a – First mention of one unspecified school.
  9. ∅ – Proper names of most mountains don’t need an article.
  10. an – “Engineer” starts with a vowel sound, so use “an.”

docs.title: Line endings
docs.text: Dealing with CRLF (Windows-style line endings) and LF (Unix/Linux-style) in a team using Git across Windows and Linux can be tricky, but it's solvable with a consistent setup. Here's how to manage it effectively:

docs.title: 1. Set .gitattributes in Your Repository (RECOMMENDED)
docs.text:
This is the most consistent way to enforce line endings across platforms.

Create a .gitattributes file at the root of your repo:

* text=auto

You can also force specific file types to use LF or CRLF:

*.sh   text eol=lf
*.bat  text eol=crlf
*.ps1  text eol=crlf
*.py   text eol=lf
*.yml  text eol=lf

Git will normalize line endings to LF in the repo and convert to the OS-specific format on checkout.

🔗 Reference: Git Book - Customizing Git: Attributes

docs.title: 2. Set Local Git Config Depending on OS
On Windows:
docs.text:
git config --global core.autocrlf true

This tells Git:

  • Convert LF to CRLF when checking out
  • Convert CRLF back to LF when committing

docs.title: On Linux/macOS:
docs.text:
git config --global core.autocrlf input

This means:

  • Leave LF on checkout
  • Convert CRLF to LF on commit

🔗 Reference: Git Documentation - core.autocrlf

docs.title: 3. Fix Existing Files in a Repo
docs.text:
If line endings are already inconsistent:

# Ensure .gitattributes is set
# Then run:
git add --renormalize .
git commit -m "Normalize line endings"

🔗 Reference: GitHub Docs - Dealing with line endings

docs.title: 4. Avoid Editor Conflicts
docs.text:
Configure your editors to match Git settings:

  • VS Code: Set "files.eol": "\n" or "\r\n" in settings.json
  • Sublime Text / IntelliJ / Vim / etc.: Configure default line endings to LF

docs.title: Top navigation bar
docs.text: You're right — the top navigation bar in Material for MkDocs only appears by default on wide screens, and only when you have the correct features enabled and enough space (depending on layout). Let’s make sure everything is set up correctly.

docs.title: ✅ Ensure Top Navigation Bar Is Enabled
docs.text: To force top-level navigation (horizontal menu), you must:

docs.title: 1. Use navigation.tabs feature (not navigation.top)
docs.text:
theme:
  name: material
  features:
    - navigation.tabs  # THIS enables top nav bar (as tabs)

docs.title: 2. Make sure your nav: structure is shallow (1–2 levels deep)
docs.text:
Example:

site_name: My Docs
theme:
  name: material
  features:
    - navigation.tabs

nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - Docs: docs.md
  - About: about.md
  - Blog: blog.md

If you use deep dropdowns, they’ll be converted to a side nav instead.
